title: Herbs for Energy: The Top 13 Backed by Science
author: Leandra Beabout
description: Stuck in a slump? These 13 herbs might help you give an energy boost. Here's what the science says.
cleaned_text: When 8 hours of [sleep](/fitness/sleep-workout-routines/) and a [healthy diet](/eat/nutritionist-tips-after-your-diet-is-over/) aren't enough, some folks turn to [herbs](/health/joint-supplements/) for energy. They can be a great way to [give you a natural boost](/eat/portable-energy-boosting-snacks/). We're talkin' [science-backed supplements](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7071459/), not sketchy remedies of course. Here's the deets on 13 herbs linked to higher energy and better focus. Say hey to one of the most common ingredients in [energy drinks](/eat/sugar-free-energy-drink/)! [Research](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5856322/) suggests that ginseng can sharpen your focus and help ward off exhaustion. Athletes even claim it boosts physical and mental performance (though more [research](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3100154/) is needed). Most [research](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5856322/) focuses on [panax ginseng](https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/ginseng-benefits#) specifically, so make sure you're reaching for the right kind at the drugstore. It's the ginsenosides, eleutherosides, and ciwujianosides in this ginseng that might give it energy-boosting powers. Ginseng dosing varies widely. Folks take anywhere from 200 to 1,000 milligrams per day. [Experts](https://www.nccih.nih.gov/health/asian-ginseng) say taking it daily seems safe for up to 6 months. Ginseng fine print Just remember that many supplements come with potential side effects. The most common ginseng probs are: There's also a risk of [ginseng](https://www.nccih.nih.gov/health/asian-ginseng) messing with meds. Chat with your care provider before popping ginseng pills if you take medicine for [diabetes](/diabetes/diabetes-breakfast-ideas/) or heart issues. What, you thought sage was just for [smudging](/live/burning-sage-smudge-stick/)? This [memory-sharpening herb](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5318325/) packs in antioxidants like luteolin and quercetin. [Research](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5634728/) indicates that supplementing with sage may improve your mood, attention, and memory. In [one study](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20937617/), 36 adults who took 50 microliters (uL) of sage essential oil performed better in memory challenges and felt more mentally energetic for 4 hours after dosing. That's because [sage is an AChE inhibitor](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5318325/), meaning it's known to improve brain function. But more research is needed, as so far, most of the research has been from cell and animal studies. Also, never ingest essential oils without your doctors instruction. Summing up sage Sage might make intense school or work projects less draining on your mental reserves. The result? More energy for the finer things in life! [Research](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25880065/) shows that guarana has four times the [caffeine](/eat/does-chocolate-have-caffeine/) as [coffee beans](/health/health-benefits-of-coffee/). It's no wonder you can find it in so many energy drinks and powders! [This herb](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4399916/) also contains saponins and tannins, which might boost energy and focus. Research is mixed on exactly how much guarana is necessary to boost energy. A 2017 [research ](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4555111/)trial suggested that taking guarana with a multivitamin before exercising could increase stamina and focus for a couple of hours. Though, because the researchers didn't test the difference between the multivitamin alone and the added guarana, it's possible the effects were due to the nutrients in the multivitamin. Potential risks Guarana is [generally considered safe](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31539257/). But like many supplements, high doses can lead to side effects like: [anxiety](/live/ways-to-calm-anxiety-and-get-sleep/) - racing heart So if you're sensitive to caffeine, this one's not for you. Bacopa monnieri (known as waterhyssop) grows in the marshes of southern Asia. For years, it's been used in [traditional Ayurvedic medicine](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5021479/) to treat mental health issues like memory loss, anxiety, and insomnia. So, what does science say? [Researchers](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3746283/) say Bacopa monnieri is full of triterpenoid saponins — ingredients that can boost your brainpower and potentially protect against [memory loss](/health/how-to-improve-memory/). Dosage depends on the person, but your mantra should be: start low, go slow. In one [research review](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24252493/), folks who took 300 milligrams of Bacopa monnieri extract daily for at least 12 weeks reported faster reaction times and clearer mental processing. Mind your dosage Bacopa monnieri is usually safe. But too much can cause: [digestive probs](/eat/foods-that-make-you-bloated/) - negative interactions with prescription meds - some issues with preexisting health issues Wanna perk up in under 5 seconds? Grab a bottle of [peppermint essential oil](https://www.nccih.nih.gov/health/peppermint-oil), close your eyes, and inhale deeply. No, seriously, try it. We'll wait. ... ... So what just happened? Well, on top of cleared [sinuses](/eat/ginger-recipes-that-will-warm-you-up/), you probably experienced a baby mood and [brain boost](/tips/chew-gum-instant-brain-boost/). [Science](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18041606/) backs this up. In one [study](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18041606/), 144 peeps who inhaled peppermint oil aroma reported feeling more alert. A PSA on EOs [Essential oils](/health/best-essential-oils-how-to-buy-essential-oils/) (EOs) are usually safe to sniff, not eat. Do not ingest them unless specifically directed by your doctor. [Peppermint oil](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5814329/) in particular can be toxic in high doses. Like [peppermint](/health/peppermint-oil-for-hair/), [rosemary](/health/rosemary-oil-for-hair/) has a deliciously refreshing aroma. [Rosemary oil](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3736918/) has special compounds called terpenes that can enter your bloodstream and directly influence your mental processing. Kinda neat, right? In one [study](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3736918/), 20 adults sat in cubicles with rosemary oil wafting from diffusers. They automatically got better at tasks that required speed and accuracy. In another [study](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30318972/), folks who drank rosemary-infused water scored better on computer-based tasks. Reasons to rave about rosemary We all know rosemary smells delish. But it may also help you concentrate and perform tasks faster. [Research](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6288277/) on Rhodiola rosea (on mice) shows that it could level up your: [endurance](/fitness/abs-workout-core-strength-and-endurance/) - alertness - memory recall One [study](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26502953/) (though not placebo-controlled) showed it might also: - calm anger - soothe stress - reduce anxiety - improve depression In one 12-week [study](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5370380/) of 118 people experiencing burnout, 400 milligrams of Rhodiola rosea extract a day helped keep the exhaustion away. They also reported [feeling more joy](/connect/investing-in-the-joy-of-others/) — and couldn't we all use a little more of that? Finally, [some research](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28219059/) suggests that Rhodiola rosea can help with chronic fatigue. Though, neither of these last two studies were rock-solid. More research is needed. Rhodiola rosea rundown It's the perfect antidote to a hellish week (or [year](/discover/mental-health-counselors/)) that makes you want to poke your eyes out. Ashwagandha has been used in [Ayurvedic medicine](/health/natural-remedies-for-anxiety/) for centuries. Fans claim this little herb has the power to boost focus and energy in big ways. Here's what the science says. In [one 8-week study](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28471731/), folks who took 600 milligrams of ashwagandha root extract each day reported better [attention span](/adhd/top-iphone-android-apps-adhd/) and memory recall. Those who took the placebo pill experience no such thing. A [12-week study](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7096075/) of 50 older adults suggested that taking the same dose daily boosts sleep quality, alertness, and general feelings of wellness. The results of another [study](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6266766/) indicate that taking 500 milligrams of ashwagandha extract could boost athletic performance. Ashwagandha 101 This herb can potentially improve your: - sleep quality - memory - alertness - attention span - athletic performance - general sense of wellness Another herb used in traditional Eastern medicine, gotu kola is often linked to [mood](/happiness/25-meals-boost-your-mood/) and focus improvements. Research is limited, but here's what we know so far. One 2-month [study](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18191355/) showed that taking between 250 and 750 milligrams of gotu kola extract a day can boost mood, memory, and mental clarity. Meanwhile, a [2011 study](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3136695/) in the elderly suggested that taking 500 to 700 milligrams per day could improve [physical strength](/move/foam-roller-exercises-the-best-moves-for-strength/) and functioning. FTW! Another [study](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20677602/) (albeit low-quality) found that taking 1,000 milligrams daily for 2 months improved attention span and reduced anxiety. Why gotu kola is a go-to Gotu kola might make you feel better in a lot of ways, though more research is needed: - less anxiety - mood boost - mental clarity - sharper memory - longer attention span - improved physical strength [Maca](/eat/maca-powder-recipes#1) has been having a moment for, like, years. There's a lot to love about this powdered adaptogen. First, there's the whole sexual performance thing (an energy of its own kind, amiright?). In one [study](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19781622/) of folks with [erectile dysfunction](/grow/erectile-dysfunction-in-young-men/), taking 2,400 milligrams of dried maca for 12 weeks made them better, harder, stronger... Second, [research](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5039502/) suggests that maca can improve overall energy and mood — and possibly athleticism. What's not to love about that? Make moves with maca Maca might help #TeamPeen perform better. It can also help boost your overall mood and energy levels. Give it up for another adaptogen! This one's a fungus rather than a leafy plant. It grows on insects — yep, you read that right — and is known for boosting energy and [post-workout recovery](/eat/vegan-post-workout-meals/). In one [study](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5236007/), folks who took a cordyceps and mushroom supplement for 1 to 3 weeks improved their workout stamina with each additional week. Other [research](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3909570/) suggests that cordyceps may [decrease inflammation](/grow/how-inflammation-affects-health-body/) (which leads to a whole mess of health probs) and has anti-cancer properties. Not bad for a fungus, eh? We love a good fungus Cordyceps might help decrease inflammation and can help you recover from your sweet sesh. It might even have anti-cancer properties. Mountain climbers, you'll recognize this one. [Shilajit](https://www.healthline.com/health/shilajit#) is a sticky, powder-like growth that grows on rocks at high altitudes. It's bursting with minerals and [fulvic acid](https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/fulvic-acid), an antioxidant that's touted by natural medicine practitioners as an anti-inflammatory agent. In one animal [study](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0378874112003893?via%3Dihub), shilajit seemed to improve symptoms of chronic fatigue syndrome. A [2019 study](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6364418/) suggested that 500 milligrams a day could significantly boost muscle recovery and endurance. Shilajit could be a great energy-boosting supplement for athletes or anyone struggling to recover from [HIIT](/fitness/best-hiit-playlist/) workouts. While schisandra isn't usually eaten as food, this berry's been used medicinally for centuries. This little powerhouse is full of [lignans](https://www.cancer.gov/publications/dictionaries/cancer-terms?cdrid=330172), which could boost antioxidant levels. That's always good news for your health and energy. One [research review](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6412213/) suggests that schisandra may supercharge your endurance and energy during workouts — but the same review states that more research in humans is needed to *prove* the connection. What we know about schisandra [Schisandra](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0753332217346243) has compounds that may boost brain function. And since it's an [adaptogen](/eat/drink-recipes-that-use-adaptogens/), it could relieve stress. We also know it's widely accepted as a supplement for leveling up general wellness and energy, though research is limited. Herbal supplements have the potential to boost your energy and focus, but they're no substitute for a healthy lifestyle. If you're feeling exhausted on the reg, it's essential to look at your health overall. Are you [getting enough sleep](/live/ways-to-calm-anxiety-and-get-sleep/)? Are you eating [healthy, nourishing foods](/health/44-healthy-foods-under-1/)? Are you moving your body and finding ways to [relieve stress](https://greatist.com/move/yoga-video-the-perfect-after-work-yoga-flow/)? If you want to try one of these herbs for energy, check with your doctor first. Though they're natural supplements, they can still mess with some meds and health conditions.
